correct: WSU pulled off a major upset, as Texas came into the game as the No. 5 team in the country. The Cougars scored 19 unanswered points in the third quarter to turn a 10-7 deficit into a 26-10 lead, eventually winning the game 28-20.

Squirt the Terrier became the mascot when someone brought a dog to campus early in the 20th century. From 1910-1919, the mascot became the Indians, and in October 1919 WSU settled on the cougar as the official mascot.

answer: The cougar was named an endangered species, so the United States Fish and Wildlife Service asked them to stop.
When the cougar died just before the 1979 season, they couldn't find another one in time so they swtiched to a human mascot.
There was a student vote, and the student body voted to discontinue the tradition.
correct: n August of 1978, Butch VI died. This prompted a debate on whether the tradition should continue, and a survey of 403 students found that 63 percent of students opposed another live cougar. Because of that, WSU President Glenn Terrell decided to end the tradition.

answer: The last cougar, Butch VI, attacked a student on the way to a game, so the school decided it was no longer safe.

The University of Idaho was the first team WSU ever played -- a 10-0 Cougars win in 1894. WSU has continued to dominate the series ever since, holding a 71-17-3 all time record against the Vandals.

In his junior season, he threw for 4,597 yards, but his 22 interceptions may have held him back in the eyes of voters. The next year, he seemed to be in the discussion again, but a broken leg suffered in November ended any hopes he add of a Heisman.
Though Babe Hollingbery holds the WSU record for most wins as a head coach, Mike Price led the Cougs in their golden era -- taking the team to two Rose Bowls and a No. 3 ranking in 2002.

In blizzard-like conditions with WSU trailing 7-6 in the third quarter of the game that would come to be known as the 'Snow Bowl,' Bledsoe hit Bobo on a 44-yard touchdown pass. Bobo slid into a pile of snow by the goalposts, and the catch sparked a 29-point third quarter that carried the Cougars to a 42-23 win and gave UW just their second loss of the season.

correct: WSU came in with only two wins, while UW was 9-1 and ranked No. 5 in the nation. But Nelson, who hadn't missed a kick all year, pushed a 33-yarder that would have given UW the lead wide right with less than four minutes to play, and the Cougars went on to complete the upset, 24-20.
